headers.header_text: A HTG 100 section 029: For International Students ONLY. To obtain a permission-to-add code, please contact the American Heritage office at amer_htg@byu.edu.
A HTG 100 section 030: For International Students ONLY. To obtain a permission-to-add code, please contact the American Heritage office at amer_htg@byu.edu.

catalog.description: Synthesis of American constitutional and economic principles, and patterns of historical development.
catalog.note: NOTE: Additional seats for specific sections may be available to Freshman Mentoring participants through envelopes. NOTE: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.title: American Heritage.

course_headers.header_text: A HTG 100: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
A HTG 100: Additional seats for specific sections may be available to Freshman Mentoring participants through envelopes.

catalog.description: Financial and managerial accounting principles. Basic accounting statements, processes, and management applications.    Open to all students.
catalog.note: NOTE: ACC 200 is a hybrid BYU online and in-class course. Lecture will be held once a week, augmented by online material. NOTE: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.title: Principles of Accounting.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 200 is a hybrid BYU online and in-class course. Lecture will be held once a week, augmented by online material. Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.

catalog.description: Introduction to legal principles and institutions affecting business.
catalog.note: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.prerequisite: Marriott School of Management major status.
catalog.title: Business Law in the Environment.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 241: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.

catalog.description: Additional issues in financial and managerial accounting.  Review of issues related to balance sheet accounts, performance evaluation and capital budgeting.
catalog.title: Principles of Accounting 2.

catalog.description: Inputs, processing, outputs, and files of several transaction-processing subsystems.  Foundation for understanding internal control.  Variety of tools used to design, create, or document accounting information systems (AIS) to achieve organizational objectives.
catalog.note: To register for the Accounting Jr. Core, choose "Add an Envelope of Classes."
catalog.title: Business and Accounting Information Systems.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 401: To Register for the Accounting Jr. Core, choose "Add an Envelope of Classes".

catalog.description: Financial reporting issues for balance sheet, income statement, and cash-flow statement.  Revenue recognition, accounting for long-term assets, investment securities, and derivative instruments; consolidation.
catalog.title: Intermediate Financial Accounting 1.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 403: To register for the Accounting Jr. Core, choose "Add an Envelope of Classes".

catalog.description: Introduction to framework providing financial statement assurance; integrating accounting and business knowledge with concepts from other disciplines such as statistics and law; framework applied to major business cycles, providing specific knowledge in financial statement auditing.
catalog.title: Financial Statement Auditing.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 406: To register for the Accounting Jr. Core, choose "Add an Envelope of Classes".

catalog.description: Advanced financial accounting topics including pensions, earnings per share, accounting changes, and deferred income taxes.
catalog.title: Advanced Financial Accounting.

catalog.description: Professional standards and professional literature of accounting and auditing; related academic research.  Research tools, information technologies, and critical analysis emphasized.
catalog.title: Accounting Research Seminar.

catalog.description: Fundamentals of academic research, including the scientific method, the philosophy of science, and the areas and methodologies of academic research.
catalog.prerequisite: Admission to the MAcc predoctoral track.
catalog.title: Introduction to Academic Research.

catalog.description: Tax laws as they apply to selected tax entities, with an introduction to tax research methodology.
catalog.title: Advanced Taxation.

catalog.description: In-depth treatment of research and procedures emphasizing communication and presentation of findings.
catalog.title: Tax Research Methodology.

catalog.description: Apply an analytic mindset to problems. Learn data analytic tools and techniques including extracting, transforming, and loading data; querying databases; visualizing data; and applying statistical concepts in accounting settings.
catalog.title: Accounting Data Analytics.

catalog.description: Accounting methodology, professional auditing standards, and current issues.
catalog.prerequisite: Admission to MAcc; Acc 515 or equivalent.
catalog.title: Advanced Financial Statement Auditing.

catalog.description: Principles of data communication and security, local- and wide-area networks, hardware, software, infrastructure, standards, policies, baseline security, web security, cryptography, operations, and security management.
catalog.title: Data Communications and Security.

catalog.description: Concepts and techniques of database system development.  Focal areas include: structures, integrity, retrieval, manipulation, validation, and analysis.  SQL used as basis for data interrogation.
catalog.prerequisite: Admission to a Marriott School graduate program.
catalog.title: Database Analysis and Design.

catalog.description: Projects-oriented course where students get hands-on experience performing consulting jobs for businesses in Utah.  Class includes both in-class instruction and business experience.
catalog.title: Management Consulting and Projects.

catalog.description: Special property transactions, accounting periods and methods, tax payments and credit, tax concepts, and reporting tax liability.
catalog.title: Special Problems in Federal Taxation.

catalog.description: Continuation of Corporate Taxation 1.  Includes consolidated returns.
catalog.title: Corporate Taxation 2.

headers.header_text: This class is ADVANCED INDIVIDUAL TAXATION.

catalog.description: Intensive study of special and current tax topics and policies.
catalog.title: Current Tax Policy.

catalog.description: In-depth study one-on-one with chosen professor on topic of mutual interest not currently covered in existing courses.
catalog.title: Readings and Conference

catalog.description: On-the-job experience and training in industry, government, or public accounting firms.
catalog.note: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.
catalog.title: Academic Internship: Accounting.

course_headers.header_text: ACC 599R: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.

catalog.description: Basic fundamentals of military leadership--drill, courtesy, planning, and organizing at various levels of responsibility.
catalog.title: Leadership Laboratory--Freshmen.

catalog.description: Development, organization, and core values of the U.S. Air Force, emphasizing the foundations of officership.
catalog.title: The Air Force Today.

catalog.description: Physical training course for Air Force ROTC members only.
catalog.title: Physical Training - Air Force ROTC.

catalog.description: This course will create a focus on the physical and mental requirements to successfully compete for a special tactics training allocation. Although the focus is on preparation for a career in special forces, any cadet in the AFROTC program can join to improve physical fitness and team building skills. Leadership, problem solving, and physical fitness will be the subject of much of this course.
catalog.title: AFROTC Special Tactics.

catalog.description: As listed for Aeros 100/101. Increased emphasis on performance level.
catalog.title: Leadership Laboratory--Sophomores.

catalog.description: Development of various concepts of air power employment, emphasizing factors that have prompted research and technological change through the early 1960's.
catalog.title: The Developmental Growth of Air Power.

catalog.description: As listed for Aeros 100/101. Students perform as cadet officers. Emphasis on leadership development.
catalog.title: Leadership Laboratory--Juniors.

catalog.description: Fundamentals of military leadership and M-1 rifle drill; emphasizes need for response to vested authority, with opportunity to develop confidence, military bearing, and other interpersonal skills; students perform as cadet leaders.
catalog.title: Leadership Laboratory--Honor Guard.

catalog.description: Writing, speaking, and listening as communication skills; management concepts; responsibilities and ethics for an Air Force junior officer.
catalog.title: Management and Leadership.

catalog.description: Air Force ROTC field leadership training course.  Provides advanced fundamentals of military leadership, planning, organizing, and team building at various levels of responsibility.
catalog.note: NOTE: Enrollment limited to Air Force ROTC cadets. NOTE: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.
catalog.title: Academic Internship: Leadership Intern Program.

course_headers.header_text: AEROS 399R: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.

catalog.description: As listed for Aeros 100/101. Senior cadets perform in leadership positions in planning and conducting all activities of the cadet corps.
catalog.title: Leadership Laboratory--Seniors.

catalog.description: Civilian control of military, civil-military interaction, the forming of defense strategy. Military profession; Russia, Europe, and East Asia regional studies.
catalog.title: National Security Affairs.

catalog.description: Basic language skills.
catalog.title: First-Year Afrikaans.

catalog.description: Offers a historical, theoretical, and practical overview of the discipline of American Studies.
catalog.title: American Studies History and Theory.

catalog.description: Selected readings, lectures, and analysis of specific motion pictures as social documents, reflecting different facets of the American experience.
catalog.title: Film in American Culture.

catalog.description: Introduce research in American Studies and Western American Studies. Speakers from BYU and other institutions share their research. Students engage with lecturers by developing questions, then evaluate and write about ideas.
catalog.title: American Studies Lecture Series: Presentations on American Studies/Western American Studies.

catalog.description: In-depth review of American Studies theories, methods, and criticism; content varies; requires original research and substantial writing of paper intended for publication.
catalog.prerequisite: Senior status or program coordinator's consent.
catalog.title: Senior Capstone.

catalog.description: Historical background, research skills, and methods of academic inquiry relevant to ancient Near Eastern Studies.
catalog.title: Introduction to Ancient Near Eastern Studies.

catalog.description: Israelite history and culture in Canaan/Israel from c. 2000 B.C. to A.D. 200.  Methodology for using the Bible in historical research.
catalog.title: History and Culture of Ancient Israel.

catalog.description: Directed individual study of historical topics or ancient texts.
catalog.recommended: Written plan of study approved by both instructor and program coordinator.
catalog.title: Directed Readings in Ancient Near Eastern Studies.

headers.header_text: ANES 392R Section 002: Studies in ancient Egypt and Archaeological Conservation

catalog.description: Topical studies in the ancient Near East based on student interest and faculty expertise.
catalog.title: Topics in Ancient Near Eastern Studies.

catalog.description: Capstone seminar utilizing research, analytical, and writing skills to produce a senior research paper on an ancient Near Eastern topic.
catalog.title: Senior Seminar in Ancient Near Eastern Studies.

catalog.description: Aspects of society and culture: kinship, beliefs, economy, and political order among peoples worldwide. Methods and perspectives used in social/cultural anthropology.
catalog.note: NOTE: Additional seats for specific sections may be available to Freshman Mentoring participants through envelopes.  NOTE: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.title: Social/Cultural Anthropology.

course_headers.header_text: ANTHR 101: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu
ANTHR 101: Additional seats for specific sections may be available to Freshman Mentoring participants through envelopes.

catalog.description: Examination of other cultures through ethnographic or archaeological film.
catalog.note: Can be taken separately or concurrently with Anthr 101 or 110.
catalog.title: Anthropological Films.

catalog.description: Studying past human behaviors and cultures by applying scientific principles and reasoning; exploring case studies concerning archaeological discoveries.
catalog.note: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.title: Introduction to Archaeology.

course_headers.header_text: ANTHR 110: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu

catalog.description: Overview of anthropology major and graduation requirements; preparing for senior thesis sequence; career opportunities; and graduate school application process.
catalog.title: Introduction to the Major.

catalog.description: Theoretical and philosophical antecedents of modern social theory; ideas and theorists that shaped the formation of anthropology as a discipline.
catalog.title: Foundations of Social Theory.

catalog.description: Ideas from the founders of social and cultural anthropology and archaeology as disciplines, particularly at the turn of the 20th century.
catalog.title: Foundations of Anthropological Theory.

catalog.description: Processes by which tools and other objects were produced anciently; experimental reproduction and use of ancient tools and their scientific analysis..
catalog.title: Experiments in Ancient Technology.

catalog.description: Relationships between human biology, environment, social structure, and culture. Concepts and data on race, primates, evolution, population genetics, growth, and sociobiology.
catalog.title: Biological Anthropology.

catalog.description: Identification and treatment of skeletal material found in archaeological excavations.
catalog.title: Human Osteology.

catalog.description: Linguistic anthropology as a way of doing ethnography; language as symbolic form, vehicle of thought, and instrument of social interaction; speech events as cultural texts.
catalog.note: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.
catalog.title: Language, Culture, and Society.

course_headers.header_text: ANTHR 309: Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu

catalog.description: Role of museums in society. Analyzing museum content, use, and sociology. Visits to and critiques of area museums. Final projects with real museums in the region.
catalog.title: Museums and Cultures.

catalog.description: Society and culture on the Indian subcontinent. Stratification, kinship, marriage, religion, politics, economics.
catalog.title: Peoples of India.

catalog.description: Cultural and social institutions of traditional and modern China, including mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, or other areas of Chinese impact.
catalog.title: Chinese Culture and Society.

catalog.description: Cultural developments of North American Indians (Canada, U.S., and northern Mexico) before Columbus.
catalog.title: Archaeological Cultures of North America.

catalog.description: Setting and context of the Bible as clarified and supplemented from archaeology, history, and related studies. Archaeological methods.
catalog.title: Archaeology and the Bible.

catalog.description: Survey of the most important sites, artifacts, monuments, and methodological approaches associated with the archaeological study of Etruria, Roman Italy, and the Roman Empire. Cultural contexts of the regions impacted by Roman civilization.
catalog.title: Archaeology of Roman Civilization.

headers.header_text: ANTHR 390R section 001: American Indian Views and Voices
ANTHR 390R section 003: Marx, Society, and Culture
ANTHR 390R section 004: Peoples of the Pacific
ANTHR 390R section 005: Peoples of the Pacific
ANTHR 390R section 006: Peoples of the Pacific
ANTHR 390R section 007: Peoples of the Pacific

catalog.description: Subjects related to a particular area or people.
catalog.offered: Offered when unique opportunities or needs arise.
catalog.title: Special Topics in Regional Anthropology.

catalog.description: Kinship theory and analysis, 1920-present.  Recent issues in anthropological treatment of gender, marriage, and family structure.
catalog.title: Kinship and Gender.

catalog.description: Social use and understanding of semiotics, signs, symbols, and other meaningful forms as critically constitutive of culture.
catalog.title: Symbolic Anthropology.

catalog.description: Weekly anthropology seminars in which anthropologists and archaeologists from across the country (as well as from the Department of Anthropology) will present their latest research. An opportunity for students to learn about the most up-to-date research currently being conducted by anthropologists and archaeologists.
catalog.title: Anthropology Seminar.

catalog.description: Analytical and laboratory techniques as part of a BYU-sponsored archaeological project.
catalog.title: Lab Skills for Anthropology.

catalog.description: Subjects related to anthropological theory or the operation of social systems.
catalog.offered: Offered when unique opportunities or needs arise.
catalog.title: Special Topics.

catalog.description: Field or library research.
catalog.note: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.
catalog.title: Academic Internship: Research.

catalog.description: Reading 2,500 pages on a stated topic.
catalog.title: Directed Readings.

catalog.description: Historical approach to development of archaeological knowledge, method, and theory, emphasizing North America and individual contributions.
catalog.title: History of Archaeology.

catalog.description: Museums in society. Cultural foundations of museum content and sociology of museum use. Analyzing museum studies literature. Visits to and critiques of area museums. Final projects in real museums in the region.
catalog.title: Museums and Cultures.

catalog.description: Core museum disciplines: collections management, curation, education, exhibition, and conservation. Supporting technologies: database, digital photography, Web design, etc. Career paths.
catalog.title: Museum Practices and Technologies.

catalog.description: Overview of ethnography and prehistory of American Southwest. Current issues in archaeological research emphasized.
catalog.title: Southwest Seminar.

catalog.description: Students will learn ethnographic data analysis methods and then they will apply these methods to their own data. They will bring their own data that they will then analyze during the course. In the process, students will learn to use computer-assisted qualitative data analysis software.
catalog.title: Ethnographic Data Analysis.

headers.header_text: ANTHR 590R Section 001: Arch of Roman Civilization
ANTHR 590R section 005: Peoples of the Pacific

catalog.description: Special topics in archaeology, sociocultural anthropology, or museum studies.
catalog.title: Special Topics.

catalog.description: Earning credit while employed in federal agency archaeology (BLM, U.S. Forest Service, etc.); or 320 hours in collections-holding institution (sixteen weeks half-time; eight weeks full-time).
catalog.note: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.
catalog.prerequisite: Prior approval; completion of all course work for certificate in museum practices (may be taken concurrently with Anthr 596).
catalog.title: Academic Internship: Federal Agency on Museum/Collections Repository.

course_headers.header_text: ANTHR 599R: An APPROVED Internship Application is required before adding.

catalog.description: Reading about 1,000 pages per credit hour and providing required products.
catalog.title: Readings.

catalog.description: Field research, data acquisition, and data analysis. Must be thesis related.
catalog.prerequisite: Completion of 18 hours of 500-level core curriculum for MA program.
catalog.title: Research.

catalog.description: Basic skills of spoken and written Arabic.
catalog.note: Suggested first class for students learning Arabic. (If all sections are full at registration, email Dr. Belnap at belnap.byu.edu.)
catalog.title: First-Year Arabic.

course_headers.header_text: ARAB 101:  If all the sections are full, please email Dr. Belnap at belnap@byu.edu
Also offered by BYU Independent Study; enroll anytime throughout year; one year to complete; additional tuition required; register at is.byu.edu.

catalog.description: Significantly expanding proficiency in Modern Standard Arabic and increasing conversational repertoire.
catalog.title: Second-Year Arabic.

catalog.description: Intermediate spoken Arabic.
catalog.title: Second-Year Conversation.

catalog.description: Advanced work in reading, writing, listening, speaking.
catalog.title: Advanced Modern Standard Arabic.

catalog.description: Extensive reading of Arabic newspapers and magazines, with appropriate vocabulary building.
catalog.title: Newspaper Arabic.

catalog.description: Advanced conversation skills.
catalog.title: Third-Year Conversation.

catalog.description: Intensive study of the spoken language.
catalog.title: Spoken Arabic.

catalog.description: Advanced conversation and rhetorical skills based on point/counterpoint debates.
catalog.title: Advanced Formal Arabic Conversation and Rhetorical Skills.

catalog.description: Essay and letter writing in Arabic.
catalog.title: Fourth-Year Arabic Writing Tutorial.

catalog.description: Movies, plays, and other texts in spoken Arabic.
catalog.title: Advanced Spoken Arabic.
